message: Last chance for Microsoft & Sony to justify the existence of Kinect & Move to gamers?

Eurogamer reckons Microsoft has 10 hardcore Kinect games lined up for the show, but I guess some of them must be things we know about (like the lame Star Wars game) and others must be arcade games. But Kinect has been selling well, unlike Move. I think we'll see another  big Kinect push at the end of the year just before Microsoft annoucnes the next-gen console in 2012

Kinect HAS been selling well.  But based on what I see here locally, though, I do strongly get the impression that its sales have been very regional.

It's never been low on stock since launch, it's been discounted off and on, and right now it's easily possible to pick it up for around 90€ — over a ⅓ off.  It seems retailers are still trying to get rid of their Xmas stock.

Plus, of course, we know that Kinect sold about three units total in Japan.

So though there seems to be some anecdotal evidence that the Kinect has recreated the Wii's original fashionability, I just don't "feel" it.

There are a couple of Kinect titles I'm interested in -- Twisted Pixel's Gunstringer, for one, and it seems that Crytek game announced last year at MS's conference is for Kinect too -- but frankly I'm hoping that MS has some *non*Kinect things to show this year. Which, unfortunately, doesn't seem all that likely :/

So the last Syphon Filter game I played was the first… so I'm obviously not the right person to answer your question.  You could say it's a Westernised take on MGS.  And I guess you could also say that some of the Tom Clancy games definitely took some inspiration for Syphon Filter.

There's a small but dedicated subculture who will claim that the Syphon Filter games are the best 3rd person stealth games ever produced.  But even they've been quiet of late, seeing as how it's been so long since there's been a mainline release in the franchise.

The PSP iterations had good reviews, as I remember.  I never did play them, but I'm sure you can pick them up for next to nothing nowadays.
Hmm, sounds promising.

Oh CRIPES.

There's this one background part of my brain that tracks things like E3 keynotes, and another much larger part of my brain that tracks things like WWDC keynotes, and the two rarely speak to each other… which is why it took me until now to realise that the E3 keynotes and the WWDC keynote fall ON THE SAME DAY this year.

In fact, the WWDC keynote starts at 10am in San Francisco, exactly an hour after the start of the Microsoft E3 conference in LA.

It's pretty much a certainty that we'll see no new hardware at WWDC this year, but it has also been officially confirmed that we'll see iOS 5, which should be of more than a little interest to gamers, what with it being likely to be a pretty important gaming platform going forward…

So… slot that Apple keynote in between Microsoft and EA;  I've updated my calendar (linked above).

I'm kind of with Broken.  It's possible to push this too far.

Give me the Team ICO Collection and the Clover Collection (*cough*) and the Jak Collection (*cough cough COUGH*), and I'm happy.  Much beyond that, and it starts to become filler… time that would best have been put to use producing original content.
There's not much else other than what's already been announced from the PS2 era that I'd like to see given the HD treatment other than what Mr_V's already mentioned. FFX would be nice, I guess.

Except Broken doesn't want the "minor hits". You know, like ICO and Jak and everything Clover ever did ;)

Jokes aside, I don't see any real danger here. These ports are small- and cheap enough projects to not draw development resources away from new and more exciting projects. Plus, they don't really sell to the masses. God of War Collection and Sly Collection both faded out of retail distribution almost as soon as they'd been released; publishers wouldn't even bother unless they knew there was a core group of fans who'd definitely buy it.
